sub_topic: Calculation of the lifetime of excited states in atoms
message_1: What is the calculated lifetime of the first excited state in an atom of hydrogen? Please provide your answer in terms of seconds.
message_2:
The lifetime of the first excited state (n=2) in a hydrogen atom can be calculated using the Einstein A coefficient, which describes the probability of spontaneous emission from an excited state to a lower energy state. For the hydrogen atom transitioning from n=2 to n=1, the Einstein A coefficient (A21) is approximately 6.3 x 10^8 s^-1.

The lifetime (τ) of the first excited state can be calculated as the inverse of the Einstein A coefficient:

τ = 1 / A21

τ = 1 / (6.3 x 10^8 s^-1)

τ ≈ 1.59 x 10^-9 s

So, the calculated lifetime of the first excited state in a hydrogen atom is approximately 1.59 x 10^-9 seconds.
